title: When the staff of Moses turned to a snake? What kind of snake was it ? How big? Did it have any special features? Did anyone describe it? - Quora

response.answer_text: Probably (but we don’t know) it was the same kind of poisonous viper which bit and killed many of the sinning Hebrews (Semites?) in the wilderness. Moses had to then build a bronze statue of a poisonous viper to hold up on a pole for the sinful Hebrews (still alive) to come and behold so that their sins would be forgiven and they themselves would not die from the bite.  Jesus compared his being lifted up on a cross to Moses lifting up the bronze statue of the viper (see Gospel of John chp. 3). Those that behold Jesus lifted up are saved too. The “apostle” Paul only has contempt for Moses and Jesus. In Book of Acts chp. 28, Paul is bitten on the hand (Mark of the Beast to the hand) by a poisonous viper. He then shakes it off (“shakes off the beast” - KJV lingo) into the fire as if to say, “It is you Moses and Jesus who will be cast into the Lake of Fire, not myself and the Anti-Christ.” I can almost hear Paul myself. Can you? If one compares Jesus’ teaching in Gospel of John chp. 3 to Paul’s teaching in 1 Corinthians chp. 10, it is apparent that Paul does not want us to understand the Grace of God exhibited through the lifting up of Moses’ viper and Jesus Christ on the cross. Paul says the episode in the wilderness is only a warning to us not to sin or else suffer the same consequences i.e. death. How pathetic is that theology! Basically, the Benjamite Pharisee wolf in sheep’s clothing, Paul of Tarsus, wants us to maintain the Pharisaic “Way” of salvation i.e. salvation through not sinning. That is NOT the “Good News” i.e. Gospel of Jesus Christ. Of course, Paul never met Jesus and never witnessed his life/ministry and passion and resurrection and ascension.

From the way it was described in the bible, the best thing we could assume would be a king cobra, which is considered the most intelligent, majestic and well-spoken snake out of all of them, and reflects and mirrors the regalness and the superiority complex of god’s personality.
